What is the Maykop culture?: The Maykop culture was a major Bronze Age archaeological culture in the western Caucasus, dating to around 3700-3000 BC.
Where was the Maykop culture located?: The Maykop culture was located in the western Caucasus, from the Taman Peninsula to Dagestan and southward to the Kura River.
When did the Maykop culture exist?: The Maykop culture existed between approximately 3700 BC and 3000 BC.
What period does the Maykop culture belo: The Maykop culture belongs to the Early Bronze Age.
After which culture did the Maykop cultu: The Maykop culture developed after the Darkveti-Meshoko culture.
Which cultures followed the Maykop cultu: The Yamna culture and Novosvobodnaya culture followed the Maykop culture.
From where did the Maykop population ori: Genetic studies suggest the Maykop population came from the south, from Imereti, descending from Chalcolithic farmers of the Darkveti-Meshoko culture.
Why is the Maykop culture important ling: The Maykop culture is considered an ideal candidate for the founders of the Northwest Caucasian language family.
Which culture bordered the Maykop cultur: The Maykop culture bordered the Kura-Araxes culture in the south.
The Maykop culture bordered the Yamna culture in the north.
What is the name of the burial site that: The Maykop culture is named after the Maykop kurgan in the Kuban River valley.
What kind of site is the Maykop kurgan?: The Maykop kurgan is a royal burial mound.
How many golden objects have been found: More than 7000 gold objects have been discovered from Maykop culture sites.
How many silver objects are known from M: Around 1000 silver objects are known from Maykop culture sites.
What is unique about Maykop culture arti: The Maykop culture produced an unparalleled amount of exquisite gold and silver artifacts for the Early Bronze Age.
Which style of art originated in the May: The Maykop culture developed a distinctive animal style in its art.
Which later cultures- art was influenced: The Scythian, Sarmatian, and Celtic animal styles were influenced by the Maykop animal style.
What kind of petroglyphs are attributed: Petroglyphs attributed to the Maykop culture remain undeciphered.
Was horse breeding common in Maykop cult: No, horses formed a very low percentage of Maykop livestock.
What animals were more common than horse: Pigs and cattle were more common than horses in Maykop livestock.
What unique horse-related artifact was f: Archaeologists found a unique bronze cheek-piece used for horse bridles.
What is special about Maykop cheek-piece: Maykop cheek-pieces had twisted loops and notches for nose and under-lip straps.
Where were some of the earliest wagon wh: Some of the earliest wagon wheels were found in the Maykop culture area, in Novokorsunskaya.
When do the Maykop wagon wheels date to?: The Maykop wagon wheels date to the second half of the 4th millennium BC.
What type of agriculture did Maykop peop: Maykop people practiced terrace agriculture in the mountains.
What do Maykop terraces indicate?: They indicate sedentary living, high population density, and advanced agricultural skills.
How old are Maykop terraces?: Maykop terraces are more than 5000 years old.
Were Maykop terraces reused by later cul: Yes, later cultures like the Scythians and Alans reused Maykop terraces.
What theory links Maykop culture to lang: It is linked to the origins of the Northwest Caucasian language family.
What genetic ancestry did Maykop people: Maykop people had a mix of Anatolian Farmer ancestry and Caucasus Hunter-Gatherer ancestry.
Did Maykop people contribute to the Yamn: Genetic studies suggest Maykop people did not significantly contribute to the Yamnaya gene pool.
What proportion of Anatolian Farmer ance: Maykop DNA contained 30%-40% Anatolian Farmer ancestry.
What was the Anatolian Farmer ancestry i: Yamnaya people had only 10-18% Anatolian Farmer ancestry.
What is Steppe Maykop?: Steppe Maykop was a population related to Maykop culture with a minor East Asian genetic component.
How much East Asian ancestry did Steppe: Steppe Maykop had about 6.9% East Asian-related ancestry.
Which ancient populations were Steppe Ma: They were connected to Ancient North Eurasians and Native Americans.
What burial practices did Maykop culture: Maykop burial practices involved kurgans and sometimes resembled Kurgan hypothesis traditions.
What type of burial structures are typic: Typical Maykop burials were large kurgans with wooden and stone structures.
Did Maykop culture influence Yamnaya met: Yes, Yamnaya metallurgy borrowed molds, daggers, axes, and copper techniques from Maykop culture.
Did Maykop culture introduce wheeled veh: Yes, wheeled vehicles may have spread to the steppe via the Maykop culture.
What was found in the Maykop kurgan?: The Maykop kurgan contained golden ox figurines, silver vessels, and thousands of precious items.
Where is the golden ox from Maykop now?: The golden ox figurine is preserved in the Hermitage Museum.
What is the Maykop plate with petroglyph: It is a plate decorated with symbolic engravings, attributed to Maykop culture.
What settlement links were noted with Ma: Links were noted with the Leyla-Tepe culture and north Ubaid period monuments.
What Syrian site shows similarities with: Tel Khazneh I in Syria shows similarities with Maykop artifacts.

Where were the Maykop mountain settlemen: They were located between the Kuban River and Nalchik, at altitudes of 1400-2400 meters.
How were Maykop mountain sites construct: They were built with oval courtyards and connected by roads.
What kind of metallurgy did Maykop cultu: Maykop culture practiced arsenical copper metallurgy and advanced metal casting techniques.
Did Maykop metallurgy use local ore sour: Yes, the Maykop culture exploited local ore deposits in the North Caucasus.
Which metallurgical technique did Maykop: They used lost-wax casting, high-temperature forging, and silver/gold inlays.
